conclusion: To calculate the distance traveled by the car within 60 seconds, we need to analyze the acceleration-time graph and use the kinematic equations.

Identify the intervals of acceleration: From t = 0 to t = 10 seconds, acceleration a1 = 2 m/s². From t = 10 to t = 30 seconds, acceleration a2 = 0 m/s². From t = 30 to t = 60 seconds, acceleration a3 = -1 m/s².
Calculate velocity at t = 10 seconds: v1 = u + a1 t = 0 + 2 × 10 = 20 m/s.
Calculate velocity at t = 30 seconds (constant velocity): v2 = 20 m/s.
Calculate velocity at t = 60 seconds: v3 = v2 + a3 t = 20 - 1 × (60 - 30) = 20 - 30 = -10 m/s.
Calculate the distance from t = 0 to t = 10 seconds: s1 = 1/2 a1 t² = 1/2 × 2 × 10² = 100 m.
Calculate the distance from t = 10 to t = 30 seconds (constant velocity): s2 = v1 × t = 20 × (30 - 10) = 20 × 20 = 400 m.
Calculate the distance from t = 30 to t = 60 seconds: s3 = v1 t + 1/2 a3 t² = 20 × (60 - 30) + 1/2 × (-1) × (60 - 30)² = 600 - 450 = 150 m.
Total distance traveled: s_total = s1 + s2 + s3 = 100 + 400 + 150 = 650 m.
Final Answer: The distance traveled by the car within 60 seconds is 650 meters.
